rComments: Professor is a very intelligible individual. Knows every date, history, geography of the middle ages. Indeed, very difficult grader but HELLO your taking an upper division literature course. Dense reading, but lecture was helpful. Do your reading, THEN ask questions.

This was the most painful class ever.  Kino----- is mean-spirited and her entire academic knowledge seems to be limited to listing the French nobility.  She is very self-satisfied, furthermore she is a poor quality teacher. Never again.

Karen is the worst professor, ever. Her lectures never made sense and never talked about the readings. She got angry one day because no one did the reading, but she didn't bother to talk about it either. The midterm should have been the final, it covered most of the class and was ridiculously hard. NEVER AGAIN.

I insist that you take another class to fulfill your World Literature requirement. As expected for an upper-division course, there is great emphasis placed on assigned texts and your ability to critically think and write about them. But obvious work aside, despite being intelligent, Kino****a is utterly boring and her lectures, sadistically so.

I can't begin to describe how terrible an instructor she is. She actually motivated me to complain to the chair of the department, that's how bad it was. Ignore the people saying that she's brilliant and challenging, she challenges you in the WRONG way and is brilliant in the sense that a dictionary has lots of definitions. Worthless - Avoid.

Kinoshita is a good professor; the readings are dense, and very difficult, but you learn a lot.  She is approachable and interested in your understanding of the material.  I felt like I was in over my head, but do the readings, attend the lectures, and ask questions. Also, make sure you have a good TA!

As a science major, I thought I would be going over my head to take this class. However, Sharon is a decent lecturer and her assignments aren't that difficult. A lot of her assignments and exams are based on her lectures. Don't complicate the assignments, just answer the questions. Attend lecture and sections and you can get an A+ easily.

like the other comments, Kinoshita is very nice and incredibly intelligent, but lecturing isn't her strong point. unless you are interested in the subject, I suggest steering clear of this class. the writing assignments weren't too bad, but the readings were really dense and difficult. you must go to lecture and section in order to get any of it.

If you choose to take this course I suggest taking it "Pass/No Pass." She teaches nearly grad-level material. I never went to her for help because she couldn't make time to meet outside of office hours. Her powerpoints are all quotes and no lecture outline. Don't take her if you can avoid it. She is brilliant but difficult to learn from.

The class was very difficult and I nearly drowned in the readings. I had no knowledge of any of the texts and no prior philosophy or critical theory background, both of which would have helped.  She's tough and monotone and it's early, but if you stick to the readings and attend class, you'll be ok.  The material can be really indecipherable though

I guess people can have different opinions of her but I'm going to try and do her some justice. She is incredibly brilliant but her voice will put you to sleep. The course materials she picked were higher post-grad level, and all she ever spoke about was that. She used a power point  but it wasn't clear and helpful and she went through it too fast.

She's definitely a tough professor and her lectures always run dry, but she is informed and always interested in hearing what students think. Keep on top of the reading and you'll do well. She's a really nice person and always willing to help.
So interesting.  She is absolutely brilliant.  And SOOOOOOOOOO hot!  She smiles sardonically all the time-how can that NOT be hot? You will learn a LOT in her class if you put the effort in.

Kinoshita was the worst teacher I have ever been forced to endure. The class was remedial at best. Don't take any of her classes, her voice alone will drive you to claw out your eyes. We spent a day talking about what "genre" means, are you kidding me? we also spent quite some time distinguishing the differences between "metaphor" and "similie"

Boring, unorganized, rambling lectures with little relevence to reading or with each other. Not to much reading but paper assignments were infuriating, pointless, and remedial. Only difficult because you have to force yourself to attend her class.

BORING!   Imaging a reality show dedicated to making crosswords!!!    She knows the material but seems not to be interested in teaching at all!   Not engaging unless she knows you from another class starting dialogs with that particular student...it feels like internal jokes, well the class was a joke and a complete waste of my time and money!

Do not take a class with Kinoshita if you don't want to work hard and be rewarded with little, but do take a class with her if you want to learn and work hard for what you get. I thought I would have no interest in the subject, but the class completely opened my mind to a world that I didn't even know existed. Definitely not for the faint of heart
Boring lectures. And expects students to think what she is thinking without much direction on her part. Not enough coverage for the material provided.
SO BORING. Avoid her at all costs.

The class was interesting, but I didn't like the prof. She was boring and sometimes unhelpful with questions. I didn't know what she wanted from me on written work, so I got a poor grade. Overall, good class material, avoid the teacher (unless she's a gues

Kinoshita is brilliant and challenging. The people i know who disliked her did so because they didn't work at understanding. She demands much, rewards sparsely. She is rigorous and thorough, and only for the serious. She also is Hottttt!!! (Extra 't's is more love.)

Horrible teacher--asks completely ambiguous questions and then is disappointed when no one can come up with the answer she's looking for.  Could have been one of the most intriguing classes--but her lectures are exceptionally boring and she butchers the students' experience of the material.
First, a brilliant scholar; secondly, an excellent teacher. Not for slackers, but well worth the effort. Closest I've come to having my mind blown at UCSC. (Medieval Mediterranean)

Very interesting woman. She often had specific things she wanted us to think about for her papers and is a bit harsh on the grading, I really liked her. The class was fascinating, she gave an interesting perspectives on history, along with great texts.

Great is not the word. Engaging is also not the word. I don't know what the word is to describe Prof Kinoshita.  Medieval French Literature could be an enlightening course, but her presentation of it was poisonous: it killed my interest in the subject.
